Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes in the Chemistry Division, Dr. Mary Cloninger, from Montana State University, will study multivalent interactions that can be used to cluster proteins. Dendrimers, hyperbranched polymers, and linear polymers bearing low and high affinity ligands will be synthesized and studied. In order to evaluate the protein/polymer aggregates thoroughly enough that guiding principles regarding formation of protein clusters can be enabled, a diverse set of experiments will be performed. Assays will include enzyme linked immunosorbent assays, electron paramagnetic resonance/chromatography assays, dynamic light scattering experiments, transmission electron microscopy imaging, fluorescence lifetime waveform spectroscopy, and size exclusion chromatography-multiangle light scattering experiments. The goal of this research is to improve the fundamental understanding of how synthetic multivalent systems can cluster proteins into defined aggregates.

Currently, good methods for controlled formation of discrete protein/polymer aggregates that can be used to study and to mediate multivalent biological recognition processes are not available. This research should enable the development of new methods for controlling the display of proteins on synthetic multivalent macromolecules and polymers. This proposal will also serve as a rich training ground for students from rural Montana and for Native American students who attend reservation high schools and tribal colleges during the school year and participate in summer programs at Montana State University. In addition, the micrographs and other results from this study will be used in presentations with local middle school students. After initial presentations by Dr. Cloninger at the school, small groups of middle school students will be able to participate in field trips to Montana State University in order to see the instrumentation and to perform experiments with polymers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background and Significance. Multivalent interactions occur when two or more molecular recognition events take place concurrently. Often, nature uses multivalent interactions to afford physiologically relevant responses for systems in which single (monovalent) interactions are too weak to be significant. One notorious example of multivalent interactions is a gecko walking across the ceiling; other examples of multivalent interactions include cellular aggregation for tumor formation in cancer, bacterial adhesion to tissue, and the targeting of pathogens by the immune system. This research focused on one aspect of multivalent interactions, namely on how multivalent interactions can be used to cluster proteins. The hypothesis that guided this program was that synthetic multivalent frameworks could be used to systematically produce protein aggregates.

Intellectual Merits. A series of carbohydrate functionalized dendrimers (highly ordered, highly branched macromolecules), hyperbranched dendritic polyglycerols (dPGs, less ordered, highly branched macromolecules), and linear polymers were synthesized and studied. The hydrodynamic radius (an important size measurement) of the polymer significantly impacts the amount of protein that can be recruited by the polymer. The molecular weight (another method of size measurement) of the polymer, on the other hand, is far less predictive of the size of the protein/polymer aggregate that can be formed. The size and polydispersity of the aggregates is also dramatically impacted by the monovalent affinity of the ligands (endgroups) for their receptors (protein binding sites). If the monovalent binding association is too strong, then the aggregates that are formed are highly polydisperse. Finally, the spacing of the receptor binding sites on the proteins impacts the likelihood that aggregates will coalesce into even larger aggregates over time or alternatively if the aggregates will disassemble over time.

Broader Impacts. The research that is described in this proposal is enabling the development of new methods for controlling the display of proteins on synthetic multivalent macromolecules and polymers. Good methods for controlled formation of discrete protein/polymer aggregates that can be used to study and to mediate multivalent biological recognition processes are critically needed. In this proposal, significant advances in the understanding of the parameters governing the formation of discrete nanoparticle formation using polymers to nucleate their formation were made. Surprisingly homogeneous aggregates were formed when ligands of appropriate binding strength were appended to the polymers, with the sizes of the aggregates dependent on the hydrodynamic radius of the nucleating polymer.

In addition, this proposal was a rich training ground for students from rural Montana and for Native American students at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels. With supplemental NSF funding for strengthening of international collaborations, a graduate student from the Mountain West received training in the synthesis and characterization of hyperbranched dendritic polyglycerols in Dr. Rainer Haag’s lab at Freie Universitat–Berlin. The PI and her students brought chemistry experiences and presentations based on this research to local middle and high school students.
